article:
Karen, Judy and I were the last ones back to the classroom after lunch.All our classmates were playing outside.
"Look at what I found in Ms.Lee's office." Karen   held up  a small box
filled with pieces of chalk in every color1 of the rainbow.
"Wow! What fun it would be to write on the  _  " Judy's eyes shone with joy. "But Ms.Lee doesn't let us do so," I responded."Don't be  _  , Janet.No one will ever know," said Karen,   _  into the box and drawing out some chalk.I  _  joined my friends in the artwork.However, I found it was funi Next we were  _  the clock all the time
in case  someone  walked in.
Then it struck Judy that we should   _  each other to writing names with our left hands.Picking up their chalk, they started.I chose a white piece.My  _  was a bit shaky, but no one would  _  that
it said "Janet".
"Better get this board cleaned off now," said Judy, erasing our handwork.Everything  came off  ...but my name! In   _   ,I was sweating and I felt my
knees  _  It wasn't chalk at all, but a white piece of
crayon on closer  _    .Mom had a saying: "Fools' names
and faces always  _     in public." I never understood   _  what it meant before.Now I did!
I rushed to the toilet to get a can of cleanser while Judy tried with   _  paper towels.After rubbing hard, my name was gone, but an abrasion   remained on the board.
Hearing footsteps coming, we  _  the
area as much as we could to remove every tell-tale trace of wetness.We were just slipping into our desks  _  the teacher
walked in.Perhaps Ms.Lee never noticed the abrasion.But I did.
Now I still remember the lesson I learned that day."No one will ever know" is never  _  .To me, living with a guilty conscience is punishment enough.
